title: How to Detect Mold in Carpet

steps.headline: Smell your carpet to see if it has a musty odor.
steps.description: Mold has a distinct, off-putting smell. If your carpet smells bad, it may be a sign that it has mold in it. Keep in mind there are other reasons your carpet may smell bad. Look for other signs of mold before you take action.

steps.headline: Look on your carpet for any black, green, or white growth.
steps.description: If you see growth on your carpet, it’s most likely mold. Unfortunately, there’s not much that can be done to clean a carpet with visible mold on it. You may need to replace your carpet.

steps.headline: Look underneath your carpet for mold growth.
steps.description: Sometimes mold grows underneath a carpet before it starts growing on the top. If you’re inspecting an area rug, turn it over and check the bottom for mold. If you suspect there’s mold growing in your wall-to-wall carpeting, you may need to hire a professional to lift up the carpet and inspect it for you.

steps.headline: Check your carpets if you’ve been experiencing bad allergies.
steps.description: A moldy carpet can produce allergens that cause you to have allergic reactions. If you’re experiencing excessive sneezing, coughing, red eyes, runny nose, or rashes, inspect your carpets to make sure mold isn’t the cause.

steps.headline: Hire a professional mold inspection service.
steps.description: Sometimes mold is buried deep in the fibers of a carpet and you’ll need a professional’s help detecting it. Search online for a local mold inspection company and have them come test your carpet. They may be able to help you get rid of any mold they find.

steps.headline: Replace water-damaged carpets if they're not cleaned in 24 hours.
steps.description: After 24 hours, there's a high probability that mold is already growing on the carpet. If it's an area rug, roll it up and dispose of it. If it's wall-to-wall carpeting, you may need to hire professionals to remove the carpet for you.

steps.headline: Check the area around a moldy carpet to see if any mold has spread.
steps.description: Look at the floorboards underneath the carpet and check nearby furniture. There could also be mold on the trim along the base of nearby walls. If you find that the mold has spread, dispose of any moldy items. Clean up the mold or hire a professional to remove the mold from your home.

steps.headline: Clean up any mold on the floorboards or walls with bleach.
steps.description: Open all the windows and doors in the room so there's air circulation. Wear goggles and non-porous gloves while you work. Refer to the instructions on your bleach container for specific usage instructions. Never mix bleach with ammonia or other cleaners or you could create dangerous fumes.

steps.headline: Know if your carpet is at high risk of developing mold.
steps.description: Carpets that are located in humid climates, below ground level, or in areas where there’s lots of water — like in a bathroom — are more susceptible to getting mold. If you have a carpet in one of these areas, try to keep it as dry as possible and frequently check it for signs of mold.

steps.headline: Clean and dry your carpet immediately if it’s exposed to standing water.
steps.description: Mold grows quickly on wet carpet, so it’s important that you take care of leaks and spills quickly. Remove the standing water from your carpet and steam clean your carpet with a carpet cleaner. Then, use fans to dry out the carpet.

steps.headline: Use a dehumidifier if you live in a humid climate.
steps.description: Mold thrives in humidity, so reducing humidity levels around your carpet will help prevent it from growing. Use the dehumidifier to keep humidity levels between 30-60 percent in any rooms you have carpet in.
